references.B05LAN01USGP: Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.A97BUS01SEGP: Busby, W.H. and W.R. Brecheisen. 1997. Chorusing phenology and habitat associations of the crawfish frog, Rana areolata (Anura: Ranidae), in Kansas. Southwestern Naturalist, 42(2): 210-217.
references.W04Ham17USGP: Hammerson, G., and M. Parris 2004. Lithobates areolatus. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2015.2. <www.iucnredlist.org>.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B71BAR01NAUS: Barbour, R. W. 1971. Amphibians and reptiles of Kentucky. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 334 pp.
references.W15NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2015. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description:
Found in southwest Indiana to south Iowa and southeast Kansas; its range does expand into the Gulf of Mexico (Conant and Collins 1998). Its distribution expands along the Coastal Plain from North Carolina to Florida; along the Gulf Coast into extreme eastern Louisiana and Texas. Also found in some drainage systems of Missouri, Mississippi, Arkansas, Ohio (Behler and King 1979). 

Habitats of preference are tallgrass or outlier prairie, wooded areas along rivers and streams, grasslands, pastures, and degraded grasslands and ever prairies converted to agricultural usage (Lannoo 2005). Its habitat is not restricted to crawfish holes, but it is often found in those that have lost their chimneys and are filled with water; also found in holes in roadside banks, storm or drainage sewers, and even small mammal burrows (Conant and Collins 1998). Breeding habitats include shallow ditches, flooded overflows, pasture ponds, and prairie wetlands (Lannoo 2005).

Damp areas, wooded valleys, oak-history woodlands and floodplains for Southern area (Dodd 2013).  Northern crawfish frog tallgrass prairie and grasslands (Dodd 2013)
